title: Addicting, but broken game and broken business model
body: What a shame we have come to in the gaming business world. I don't mind DLC, as long as it feels like an expansion to the game, not something that was purposely taken out to be sold later. I had that feeling with SimCity throughout. When I originally bought the game, I easily put 60-70 hours into it within the first two weeks, but a few things happened. One, I had a hard time dealing with the very restrictive map sizes of the game. Too many times did I have to destroy and rebuild just to fit the map size, and I just got bored of that. Two, there just aren't enough features to sustain long term play, unless you want to buy into the DLC, which is pricey. Compared to its predecessors, the game felt like half a game to begin with. Third, the forced online component just kills the single player experience. Why do I have to play with others if I don't want to? And if I don't want to, why must I take on another City to make up for the lack of space in my original one? And on top of that, I don't find people who actually want to play a smart cooperative game. Unless you have friends that are just like you and really want to play that way, you're basically gonna have a hard time finding good players. All in all, I could've given this a 1 star like many have, but I was engaged to a certain point before I realized how poorly implemented this game was. Just sad really.

title: This is not Sim City, it is Sims City.
body: When this game was first announced I thought it was going to be an updated and vastly improved version of Sim City 4. The reality however is that this game is not a sequel to the sim city series with the open ended game play and god like abilities given in the past but is a restrictive world that is simply a Sims City. The God like feel that made the all other Sim Cities so great is missing greatly from this game. I have never been a fan of the Sims, yet this is the game EA has created, an expanded Sims universe on a regional scale, not a 10 years advanced Sim City that improves upon what made Sim City 4 so incredible. I am sad to say that after 20 years of Sim City This game has destroyed my love of the series. If you love the Sims, you will love this game, but if you are a true Sim City fan, the one Will Wright created you will be sorely disappointed and cheated.

title: Worthless Piece of Garbage
body: I am a huge fan of the Sim City games and have been for years. I was thrilled when I heard that a new Simcity game was being released and I couldn't wait to start playing my favorite, but now updated, game. I purchased the game through a local retailer and I wish now that I had read the reviews before wasting $60.00. This is a completely unusable piece of garbage software that simply doesn't work.First off, creating a game such as this that can only be played and stored through an online server is a disaster. I prefer private gaming and relying upon the speed and capability of my personal computer. However, this is not possible with Simcity 5. BUT, if I could only GET to the server, that would be further along than I have been able to get.After installing the game, the game will not run. I've installed and re-installed the software four times to no avail. The only message that I get is 'there is something wrong with the installation of this game, please reinstall.' The one time that I was able to get past this window (after the fourth install), I got to the 'select server' portion of the game only to discover than clicking on the connect to server button shut the program down. After a number of tries, I finally gave up and uninstalled the game from my system.I've had my fair share of games that, once installed, I did not care for. That's part of the risk in any purchase such as this. But to have spent $60.00 on a software program that is this flawed is completely inexcusable, particularly since I can't get a refund of the money spent.EA, you REALLY messed up on this one and you are deserving of the scorn that is being directed your way!My advice is to absolutely avoid this game unless you're a fan of throwing your money away. The bucks I spent on this hideous mess of computer programming would have been better spent picking up the dog poo from my back yard. Worthless!

title: ***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***Boycott EA***

title: $60 To Stare At A Server Clock!
body: 'Your server is experiencing very high volume. You are now in a queue. The play button will become active once space is available. To play immediately please select another server.'18:59 until retryWhat not mentioned is the fact that you must create another freaking city/region regardless, because your city/region doesn't transfer from server to server. I enjoyed the game when I was playing it, but darn it when Im forced to log into a server that doesnt work or is too busy then I definitely cant recommend this game for purchase.

title: A good game ruined by EA
body: Don't be fooled by the high game reviewer scores, while the game proper is a good, albeit simplified and enjoyable game, it is the EA(Origin) DRM wrapper that ruins it. If you buy this you will never own the game or your saves, you only licence them from EA for however long they decide to keep the servers alive and EA is notorious for killing off games before their time. That's right you're not allowed to save or load, must now log in and queue a la MMO and are locked out of the game as soon your connection to the servers is lost, all this for a private single-player experience. It's a sloppy attempt at multi-player, wedged into a single-player game in a thinly veiled attempt to hide the draconian DRM and the forfeiture of your rights as a consumer. If you don't want this to become the standard for all games, vote against it with your hard earned dollars.

title: Tainted view of EA forever
body: This is a single-player game at heart and EA/ Maxis ruined it with Origin. 8/10 of the times I have had a few minutes to log in, either the service was down, a 20-30 minute queue was required (longer than I had to play) and when I have been able to log in, it often isn't to the same server where my first city resided.My first city fell victim to the Origin service going down while I was building it.Suggested resolution: $20 partial refund to all users who purchased the game release week. Remove Origin requirement.Will not buy another EA/ Origin game again. Also will not buy an EA console game.

title: Taking A Hour To Load A Single Player Game
body: I don't think this is quite as bad as the Diablo III launch. EA will state that the servers are just too 'overloaded' and that no server system could possibly handle 80 bazillion people playing.But if you buy a game, you expect to play it. That's how it always worked. Nowadays you gotta wait a week after the launch day. I've never heard of 1 hour loading times to play single player. That's crazy. EA must think we're all unemployed and don't have jobs or families or s*** to do.And even then, if you get in, you're still playing with fire. Will the server boot you out? Will it actually save your city? Why can't you save your game, destroy your city, and reload your game? Why is the city so small? Why do I need other mini cities? The endless questions.I've heard that this is a $80 facebook game. People are rightly pissed off of the poor customer feedback and getting ripped off. The always online DRM is just not the way to go. People understand about pirating games and whatnot, but making it so people can't play the games is bad. Steam has it's problems but it's gained my trust. Origin? Dear Lord. No way am I touching that weak thing.And EA wants to make money too. But inadequate servers and a 'eh' to people mad about the purchase to your product doesn't help things.EDIT: Actually, it is worse than the Diablo III launch. It's been about five days now and this has become more than 'whiny butthurt videogamers who will buy the next EA game'. It's not about the game anymore. It's about the worst videogame launch...ever. They were seriously, seriously unprepared. People can't play the game. And the always online deal? Does that even make sense for a single player game?It's a good lesson for any videogamer to learn is that you need to WAIT until you make a purchase. Don't believe the hype, the pics, the pretty words, your fanboyism, or one or two reviews. Wait until the dust settles, and then make your choice. Don't pre-order. Don't buy at midnight. Wait.Of course, how much you want to bet EA or some other bunch of boobs try this thang again and see it blow up in their faces.And you're really gonna trust this game 3 months down the road after everything has been 'ironed out?' Good luck, and god speed.

title: Decided Not to Purchase Because of DRM
body: I'm a longtime SimCity fan and have owned and enjoyed every SimCity game since the series inception way back in the late 1980's & early 90's. SimCity 2000 devoured chunks of my youth whole. Later SimCity 3000 was the mainstay game of the early 2000's on my PC along other greats such as Diablo II and StarCraft. SimCity 4 was good in it's own ways even if it didn't appeal to me in the same magnitude that it's predecessors did.The pedigree and nostalgia I have toward this series is what makes my ultimate decision to not purchase the game so difficult. Unfortunately, companies like EA have got to get the message that implementing DRM (digital rights management) such as requiring users to be constantly connected to the internet to play a game that is heavily slanted to the single-player experience is not okay. Forcing persistent connections to overwhelmed servers and implementing wait-times to play my game is not my idea of a 'good' gaming experience. Taking my save files and holding them hostage on a remote server is not my idea of a 'good' gaming experience.Very disappointed. I will not be purchasing this SimCity and if EA has any thought to the fans of the series - you know the people who buy the games - they'll remove this DRM and stop punishing their fans/customers.

title: Fun for a few hours, if you could play it (Updated)
body: Very rarely do I give 1 star reviews, but if I spend $60 on a game, I expect to be able to play it. I ended up getting 5 hours into a city (after waiting 20 minutes in a queue to play a game), only to get issues with my city 'not processing properly'. I was forced to do a roll back, and lost 2 hours of work. I spent another few hours getting it back to the way I had it before my save started having problems, and went to sleep. Now, today when I try to load my game, I get the following error: 'Unable to load city at this time. Please Try Again Later'. I have no idea if my save is gone for good, or if it's a temporary problem. The server status is green and is supposedly working, but I can't load my city.If I could play the game perfectly without any problems, I'd give it a 2/5 at best, because I literally filled the entire map up in less than 5 hours of gameplay. The excuse EA gave in making small maps is mediocre at best, and it shows how wrong they are in the early reviews. They say they want to give us maps that size because it might lag people with slow computers, but what about the people with good computers who want to have a map they can build in for longer than 5 hours without filling it up completely? Apparently in their eyes, multiplayer gameplay can only be as large as the weakest link.Besides the obvious drawbacks in the map size, the entire game seems to be 'dumbed down' from Simcity 4. No subways, no water pipes, it's almost as if the game was made for Facebook. There are major graphical issues as well, and tile problems. For example, I had a bridge across a river, and I accidently made it a suspension bridge (Which looked horrible, because there was only a single 'tower' on the bridge), so I removed the road completely. However, when I tried to make another bridge in the exact same place, it said it was too steep. Since there is no way to go back to a previous save besides having your save glitch and being forced to do it, I hadto end up bulldozing 5 skyscrapers just to fit a bridge in.All in all, it's been a disappointment so far. I can't play my save at all, even though the server seems to be working, and the map can get filled up in a few hours of gameplay. Oh, I also remember playing for about an hour while I had lost connection to the SimCity servers, which wasn't because I was offline, it was because of some server problems with SimCity. Nothing I did saved, I ended up having to start over again.Update: It's now been almost 36 hours since I was last able to play my save, SimCity support won't tell me if it's a server problem or if it's gone for good, so I'm going to create a new save on another server. Very disappointing.

title: Extremely disapointing

title: Game STILL broken
body: 1 week later and we still have major server issues. Even though it might work for a few people, just take a look at EA forums to see a sea of angry consumers unable to load their cities. This DRM excuse is a JOKE. I don't need to be online 24/7 to fully enjoy this particular game. In fact, there are many users testing how far they can go without Internet connection once they're ingame. And guess what: 99% is done inside YOUR computer, unlike EA/Maxis stated. They servers exist only to load and save games. AND THAT'S IT. They turned off all other main reasons for online play (Achivements, leaderboards, multi-city play). What's the point of this DRM crap then??? They can't even store a save game. It sucks to invest a good ammount of time in a region to see it all lost on a server error. Server problem asides, the bugs. Oh my dear Lord, this is game is INFESTED by nasty bugs. Do a quick search and see what I mean. 1/10 of your city actually go to work, there's no commute, traffic/pathfinder is glitchy as hell, services stop working randomly (had major budgjet problems cause of that), and many many many other issues. We all paid $60~$80 AMERICAN DOLAR to play beta testers. Shame on you EA, shame on you! STAY AWAY OF THIS GAME!

title: Really disappointed, and not because of the server issues...
body: I've been a die hard Sim City fan since the beginning, and I have to say, I'm really disappointed in EA and Maxis' latest offering.I luckily did not have any of the server connection issues others had. But even without those problems, the game has several flaws that ruin it for me. It seems obvious that EA's ham fisted DRM and DLC approach to game building is taking over, as right out of the box you feel like you are missing major content that should have been included in the $60 'Limited Edition'.The maps are TINY! I mean, picture the smallest map size in SC4, cut it in half, and that's about the size of the maps you get in Sim City. I laugh browsing through the achievements; some of them, like reach 1,000,000 population, I can't even see how it would be possible. I've already completely filled my map area and I barely have 15,000 people. If you were hoping for SC4 style gameplay, with massive cities and connected suburbs, you can forget it. Even Cities XL seemed to do this aspect of the game better than Sim City.The road building is better, but they left out some key features, like filler tiles and steep grade bases for many buildings, which leave your cities looking glitchy and with empty areas around zones. It would be nice if they had some filler tiles that you could use to fill in dead space like in Cities XL. Also, the building variety is terrible, and it doesn't seem like there are any options for user created content like there was in SC4, so I'm guessing you'll just be building the same city over and over again until you just get tired of the game in a month. Although, I can bet EA will be adding 'content' like buildings later and charging you an arm and a leg for the 'privilege' like they've done on other Sim titles of late.The always on DRM internet connection requirement really sucks. If you enjoyed playing SC4 while traveling, you can pretty much forget it. Sim City is supposed to be a solo activity. I can understand that some people like the multiplayer addition, but to require always on connection for everyone is just plain stupid.This is just the tip of the iceberg. The point is, if you like The Sims, Cities XL, or Sim City Societies, you'll probably like this version as well. But if your hoping for an updated version of SC4, you'll be very disappointed, just like I am.(EDIT) 3/17/13OK, so after playing for a couple weeks, I've come across yet another major flaw. So the game's always on connection means that your game saves are stored to the server or something, and the game makers in all of their wisdom have decided that you don't need an option to save the game on your own, and that it will save it for you. It's hard to click on that 'quit' button without hitting save first, your brain is telling you not to trust the game to save your work for you, but oh well, it works, right?Well, no, it doesn't work. Lately (about 60% of the time) I've been getting an error message that the game is not 'processing correctly' and asking if I want to roll my city back to a stable point, or abandon the city completely. So the big project I've been working on for the last two hours is now completely gone and I'm back to where I was when I started today. If only I had a save option so I could save my work. Thanks guys, that's quite a 'feature'.I wish games were returnable and I could get my $60 back.

title: EA screwed the pooch, but is working on it.
body: Cons:1. (SEE 2) Repeating the tutorial after every crash2. (FIXED) Crashes oftenI haven't had a crash in a while. Cities are synced upon exit, haven't had an issue here. The tutorial appears to be linked to the server.3. (FIXED) Stuck syncing to servers when logging inA work-around for this for Windows 7 and 8 users, is to run this as Administrator. Additionally, you may have to run this in Vista SP3 compatibility mode (YMMV).4. (FIXED) Not saving anything (have repeated tutorial 3 times... none of my cities survive)5. (FIXED) Horrible login queuesThough this could be to the bungle that is launch and the fact few are playing.6. Some game mechanics appear to be broken; i.e. traffic, R vs. C vs. I zoning (You can make completely Residential cities), trading, emergency services, etc. See the official forums for a list of bugs.Pros:1. Fun!Even with the bugs it is fun. You can just Recycle > Alloy/Plastic > Processors > Trade Depot > Trade Port > TVs your way to millions per month profit if you want. But I like to try and play the game as designed. Set challenges for yourself; like I am doing a mostly R and C city with recycling, etc; make a spaceport or archaeology.Overall:1. Don't spend the $80 for the Digital Deluxe.2. Get the base game.3. It has bumped Skyrim for me for now as my post-work entertainment.4. Fun was always 5 Stars.5. Overall score bumped from 1 to 3 stars.

title: DRM / Server Issues / Unstable POS
body: Update: It has now been almost 2 months since release.  Servers have calmed down a little, but BSOD still haunts me. . can't stay in game over an hour or so without the whole PC crashing.  I'd love to say I have a crappy PC and its me.. but its not... fairly new desktop pc and works fine with ANY OTHER GAME.  Even if it was at 20 bucks I still could not recommend this game..__________________________________________________________________________I played betas 1,2, and 3.... each one got better and better. Final release comes out and I'm having issues I haven't had since beta 1... such as BSOD which happens only on sim city and only on my main pc... (driver?)  It ran smooth in beta 3...The always online DRM has shown how bad it truly is... many people who bought it simply can't log in... And instead of having a  teired server system... each sever is seperate like an MMO so if you save a city on one server you have to be on that server to play it again. Que times to log back into your servers are making it hard to continue any games.  Servers are also crashing atm.  Some issues are to be expected, but 3 closed betas and no open beta tells me they didn't care much about ironing out the issues before launch.  Just now i've waited in que for 40 mins to get into my game and its still counting.  Thats after a BSOD followed by a server crash as soon as I got back in :-/ ....My advice is do not PREorder any EA titles... wait 3-7 days after release and see if it's any better.The actual gameplay for this game is fairly fun. City sizes are too small, and like others say  I am disappointed you can't edit the roads in the regional view... old versions of sim city could connect every neighboring down directly with roads... not so in sim city.. you can have 2 sitting right next to each other and only have rail.. water.. or nothing to connect them directly..The always on DRM also scares me cause EA is pretty bad about shutting down servers after a year or 2... we'll see...Until they remove the DRM / fix all the issues my recommendation and review score will stay as a PASS and a 1 star...

title: And you think this is a 1 star game?

My experience was 90% good, with only minor, mostly annoying issues.But over all:Graphics A-  Game play  A  repeat playing A.  Road construction A+. Complexity of the supporting charts graphs.  A+. I hope they don't try to destroy every company that does not give them what they want in the first few days after a major release. It's not a perfect game, but it's. pretty darn close. I think we should stop whining like children and see what we can do to keep Maxis aware of flaws.  Keep this in perspective.  This a computer game, not a.  $5000 TV.  Give them time.Overall:  it's a 5 star game (amazingly immersive)

title: Sim City the Objective Review
body: Okay so, yes we all know that EA botched the release something horrible. Oh snap nobody in their right mind only spends an hour on a game oh we couldn't anticipate that...blah blah blah. You could have anticipated that. Hire more smart people. Anyway beyond that a lot of people are complaining about the *ONLY ONLINE* playability. It keeps people from pirating, pretty sure thats not why they did it. Maxis made a press release about their vision. Now, Sim City right now is a decent little game, but if they take it further with patching into the realm of a true MMO good on them, do it. Either way, the game is amazing...disclaimer when it works. They still have a lot of glitches going on and they need to get more people on it. Perhaps get some fresh people. I know me and a lot of other people get this error where the game crashes your entire computer after you meet the good old blue screen of death that you didn't know existed past Windows 2000, or whenever you finally stopped seeing that thing. I wouldn't recommend buying this at full price but like I said when it works this game is amazing, and I'm excited to see where they take it. If they don't drop the ball and give up this could be a constantly evolving masterpiece.

title: EA blows hard
body: If this game were any worse I would literally sue EA for giving me irritable bowel syndrome. The only thing this game does is simulate an 1858 version of London.Above all else, this is why people are downloading EA products. If some back burner basement hack crew can get a game working better and quicker than a multi-billion dollar publisher, then that basement hacker deserves my money. Unfortunately, they do it for free.

title: SimCity - 'Limited' Edition - They got that right!
body: Game is a joke. Bought for my son and nothing about it has been fun for him or me. Initial install off disc and the terrain graphics do not work. I had to uninstall and download off Origin. Finally the terrain graphics work and my son cant ever get online as no servers are available. Total waste of time and money and to make matters worse I pre-ordered from Amazon to get $20 off next purchase and have yet to see that email for $20 come through either.

title: I feel cheated
body: I should have expected that EA would piece meal the product. I completed my first city in under two hours... TWO HOURS. This is insane! City's should take countless hours to fund and build... not hours! This is not because the game is too easy but rather EA has decided to severely limit the size of the city you can build. Like other games EA is releasing, downloadable content and add-on expensions are becoming the norm which likely means we will see a update soon that allows me to 'purchase' the right to expand my city.Furthermore, goodluck getting online and playing for two hours. The servers are so overloaded it is almost impossible. With such a few building options in this release, I can hardly reccomend this to even veteren sim city fans such as myself. The economy controls they introduced are nice but I am more then happy to continue playing sim city 4 and rival sim Anno 2024 until a alternative comes up.This game is not worth the current asking price. Perhaps at 29.99 It would be a worthwhile purchase.

title: Connection error
body: EA's sheer arrogance to demand that consumers withstand always on DRM has once again underlined their unequalled inability to provide the servers required for the launch of such a game.Fools.

title: Too many issues for a potentially great game
body: Sim City is a series of proud and storied tradition, but there are a lot of significant issues here. The always online nature is irritating, but is made worse by the fact that you can't actually stay connected. Tack on long queue times and irritating DRM and you have the worst entry to date in this franchise. Save your money. This thing is a dumpster fire.

title: love it
body: My son loves this product.  He has some of the other ones sim city made too.  It is a fun game.

title: EA destroys another game
body: I loved the old Simcity. I played the first one in 1980's as a kid and every one since. I was even looking forward to this one from watching the design that went into it and the game mechanics. What I didn't realize is this game is unplayable as single player. It forces you to be in servers with many different people even if you just want to mess around by yourself and play the game on your own computer. And then the servers don't work either. I could not get one game to start so far. EA and their horrible DRM has ruined another game. I'm sure the server issues will be fixed sooner or later, but if there isn't a solid single player mode that doesn't require you to be connected to the internet all the time, then this will probably just be a blown 60$ for me. Lesson learned, EA will ruin any game you have loved for years with their oppressive grasp for cash DRM style.

title: Great Game with a S**ty Publisher
body: It's a great game and Maxis certainly has outdone themselves, but what a shame that's another great franchise ruined by EA.

title: Needs work.
body: First, I enjoy the new engine and understand that SimCity is intended to be a brand new game, not a refresh of the grid based past versions.This game could be so great, but there are a few fatal flaws currently.1) The small city sizes make using the new curved roads a decision where you must weigh space efficiency against an aesthetically pleasing or unique city design. City sizes need to increase.2) The limited road network options leave me yearning for more road layout options. One way streets, overpasses, roundabouts, and traffic circles.3) No option to play single player, offline. EA Games deciding protecting their intellectual property is more important than letting their consumers the product they've paid for.Disappointing start, maybe they will fix it. At the core this game is great and it has so much potential. Hopefully it will not be as paid DLC, necessary to make this the game it should have been from the start.

title: It seems EA Wanted a MMO at the expense of playability.
body: The graphics are a step up from the last version but the cities a way too small.  Cities are connectable, but it still doesn't help the fact that they are hard to manage when they can't grow.

title: Hard to review a game that won't even start
body: It's impossible at this point to say if the game is any good because it doesn't work. That isn't to say it has bugs, it's flat out impossible to even get it to start. EA's decision to force an always-on server connection is only tolerable as long as the backend infrastructure can handle it. This is clearly not the case here.

title: Garbage
body: Always on DRM has ruined the experience, the same issue as everyone else reviewing here. If they were to fix this it would most likely be an enjoyable game.

title: Wow now i play... oh wait
body: Got stuck on log in screen never played, so bad no point even thinking about buying it. just get another city builder

title: Worthless waste of time
body: I remember Sim City as this game where you built cities, designed infrastructure, and then destroyed it all with disasters. It seems they totally changed the way you play and now all you do is click on a button... 'Server not available try again'. Friends let me tell you, it's not NEARLY as much fun.

title: Boycott Please..
body: All the talk about how bad the DRM is.. is in fact true.  Terrible that you can't play at all without an internet connection.  Even with an internet connection, you won't be able to log on as all the servers are busy.  A simple compromise would have been to at least let the single player and tutorial mode play without a connection.  This is greed at its worst.

title: Doesn't Work, Huge Disapointment
body: You are better off buying Simcity 2000.  I don't even know if the game will be good, I haven't been able to connect to play, right now I guess I can use it to zone out and meditate.

title: Game play is nice but
body: I think the game is neat, I havent played a sim city in 15 years but I really like it,  What I dont like is the constant internet required and that it has to update to play.  I want to sit down and play it for like an hour then I got to wait 30 minutes for it to update or origin to update before I can play.  Just a bit annoying.

title: SimCity: Extremely Limited Edition
body: Launching a game which requires an 'always-on' connection is an art it seems, nearly every major product with this requirement has had a severely frustrating start. SimCity 5 and Diablo 3 share a few key similarities; both were in development for the better part of a decade with almost nothing to show for it, and both have 'always-on' requirements. The companies claim this is to 'enhance' the experience by allowing the user to have friends lists and share their video game achievements with everyone else whether they want to or not, but everyone knows the real reason for the 'always-on' requirement is to prevent piracy.Sure, protecting your bottom line is a good reason for doing something, but for the love of god, why can't these companies ensure the legitimate player can actually use the product? A decade of development, ten years to work out all the bugs, and this...this catastrophic failure on every level is the result? If I didn't know better, I would suspect Jay Wilson worked on SimCity 5 when he wasn't ruining other beloved franchises.TL:DREA has released a horrible broken game and doesn't seem too concerned it's a stagnant,gigantic,smelly and expensive whale turd.

title: Not as expected!
body: I was looking forward to playing this game, but a couple of things ruined the experience. First, I was not able to get on the server (everyone who purchased this game the week of the launch, knows what I am talking about), and second, the graphics were disappointing. The sims looked like Lego people (Ugh!!!!). I think that Sim City 4 is much better. I gave it 3 stars because the real appeal is the social game (jinvites to other regions, social media).

title: Useless
body: Absolutely terrible. Can't use the game as it is always online. The servers crash and the save files are not localized. Absolutely horrible. I will never buy a product  from EA at all. Too bad the developers got screwed over by the evil corporation EA.

title: Overbearing Copy Protection For The Lose
body: The decision to make this single player game require persistent connection to online servers will go down in gaming history as one of the worst ever.

title: Do you like SimCity? Then do not buy this game!
body: So, first of all, I got the game on March 5th, and I played it for several hours. Honestly, during that time the game was genuinely awesome and fun. The simulation is great, and the details, sheer level of development and thought put into everything is truly impressive. Evidently many designers, modelers, programmers, and other talented people worked extremely hard on this game. So, before I detail the reason for my one star rating, I would like to commend them for that hard work and give them my condolences for the sad death of their great game that occurred to reasons that were probably beyond their control.The day after I got the game (March 6th) I started it up, ready to continue building my cities, but it couldn't connect to the server I had originally used. I didn't realize at first just how serious of a problem this was until I tried to connect to another available server, only to find that the cities I had built were nowhere to be found. Eventually I found out that the cities you build are ONLY saved on EA's servers and ONLY on the server you select at the beginning of the game. This includes private games you play by yourself!!! Furthermore, if you don't have an internet connection or if EA's server fails you CANNOT play the game AT ALL!This means that for 4 hours on March 6th I couldn't play the game I had just payed $60 for because the server where I had stored my city was unavailable. After this, needless to say, I called EA and asked for a refund. Of course, this was only after hunting for 45 minutes on EA's site for some kind of way to call them on the phone, finally finding a 'Call Back' service, talking to a 'Game Advisor' for 15 minutes, talking to a supervisor for 30 minutes, being told several times I couldn't get a refund, and finally having the supervisor give up and issue the refund he adamantly told me I couldn't get.All in all, not only do I not recommend SimCity to anyone, I don't recommend EA as a companyin general, and this includes all of their games on the PC. Their Origin service is just a glorified way of forcing always-on anti-piracy measures for their games and their customer service is dishonest and frustrating. Although the game itself is good, it is useless if you can't have control over where you save or if you can't play on your own offline. Please, don't make the same mistake I did! Avoid this game at all costs!!

title: Great Game Stupid EA
body: I am agreeing with most people and am saying EA dropped the ball on SimCity. Don't get me wrong the few hours I have played this game it's been quite engrossing, but in order to play you have to be connected to the internet and that really really sucks. It sucks because EA screwed something up with the servers and it hard to even get on a server to start playing. Us gamers are like crack addicts. If a drug dealer (EA) promises us great crack and we pay lot for it then realize it just salt, we get a little agitated.

title: The game is not playable and I can't get a refund from Amazon.
body: Servers never accept connections for this 'Always On' game.  Simply not playable.  I've tried to return it to Amazon but they will only offer a replacement.  I wonder how many times I can initiate a replacement before they will finally give me my money back.

title: I paid for this?
body: I received my SimCity disc today, inserted into my PC, and then watched it install.  And then had to authenticate from the interwebs and then download even more.  Took a bit, but I understand day 1 patches - only got the disc for the 'free' $20 from Amazon.  Annoying, but understandable.  Here I sit, 6 hours later, unable to play.  Why? Because EA has no idea what they're freaking doing and can't keep servers up to save their collective asses.  The always-online, seemingly common rollback problem makes it seem as though EA never saw what happened with D3.  If you make that always-online decision and can't keep enough servers up, you're by definition incompetent.  Do NOT buy this game for at least 3 months, and even then, move on to better and more interesting games.

title: ALWAYS ON DRM, NO.
body: I don't support Always on DRM, and I don't support ridiculous measures to stop the over exaggerated threat of video game piracy. Don't ruin a not pirated game over the potential threat of Piracy.

title: I hope bears infiltrate EA headquarters and eat everyone.
body: I tried clicking as far to the left of the leftmost star but it still made me give the full star.  I think this rating system is flawed.  I have a perfectly capable kitchen toaster that could have preempted the game's launch better than EA.

title: May be good in the future...
body: Update 3/9: I've been able to play today without problems. They have finally fixed some of the initial server issues and it seems like the worst is behind us. I'm still waiting on them to fix some of the bugs and some of the options they turned off to minimize server load (i.e. cheetah speed). But playing today has been enjoyable. I'm upgrading my review to a 3. Once they fix the aforementioned issues and hopefully enlarge the city map size, I will be a happy camper. Could be a 5 star game once all is said and done!I've had this game since it released on March 5th. I waited anxiously all day for the UPS guy to come. He finally arrived around 3pm, and with that, I rushed upstairs to install and play! After a few minute installation, I was greeted with an hour long update download and installation. No problem, right? I'm patient. I've been waiting almost 10 years for this to come out, so what's an extra hour? But here we are, 3 days into the launch and I still have yet to play a single second of the game. This whole server business is for the birds. I just want to play my own little city in my own little world on my own little computer. But nooooooo! I must be connected to EA servers, which they have 8 of for the ENTIRE world to play on. Awesome. I hope they fix it soon so I can update this review with something more positive, but at this point, I'd give it no stars if I could. I'm so frustrated!

title: I'm the fool
body: I should have known after getting Diablo 3 that the always online requirement was/is a disaster.  Well, EA has been able to pull out the stops and have a horrible launch experience.  So far, I've clocked two hours, had four crashes and not been able to play in roughly 24 hours.  From what I've seen so far of the game, the maps are really small and the game feels heavily restrictive.  I would not recommend this game to anyone.  Vote with your wallet and avoid the game and get your money back if you can.

title: SIMCITY ruined
body: No local saves, cant play single player game without persistently being connected to the internet. Cant play when servers are busy or down, and what will happen when EA shuts the servers in a couple of years.

title: Electronic Arts will here from lawyers
body: This game is defective, if you pay for a product that you are unable to use because it wasn't engineered correctly, you should be able to return it for a refund.  I want my money back, and after the way customers have been treated, I want to see EA put out of business forever.  This is ridiculous, and AMAZON should step up, and pressure EA to refund everyone.Update:Yep the servers just died again, they added 4 additional servers, and they still aren't able to keep up.  I want to hear from a class action lawyer.  I want my money back, or I want the game updated so that I can play it unencumbered by their servers indefinitely.  I don't think that is unreasonable.Obviously a significant number of people are angry with Electronic Arts for the debacle.  The lesson here should be, stop forcing applications to DIE when you're servers go down.  We get it, you want a revenue stream, and you're trying to move us towards service based games where we pay you forever.  Certainly some game will bring that kind of revenue, but this isn't that kind of game.  EA, you should have done your homework and honored the franchise.  SimCity isn't the kind of game that you can turn into a subscription based cash cow.  I don't want Farmville, if I did, I'd play on Face Book FOR FREE.  The quality of the simulation is what makes SimCity fun, not playing with random strangers all over the globe (which YOU CAN NOT DO ANYWAY).Get a clue, remove the encumbering server requirement, allow for reasonably sized cities, or start issuing refunds, before the lawyers do.  When your customers start petitioning the White House, it's not just a botched release, you are in full damage control mode.

title: Vile, Orwellian Cash Grab
body: They didn't have to do this.  On it's own it's a passable, if VERY oversimplified, little game.  (And cities are indeed LITTLE) But EA's paranoid insistence upon always-on DRM has hoisted them upon their own petard.  So, if you buy this game you won't even be able to play.  And while server issues MIGHT get better, you will ALWAYS be at the whim of EA... even if you just want to play solo.Avoid this like the plague.

title: Horrible Game
body: The title pretty much says it all. I bought this game at launch and have been able to play the tutorial. Not only because the servers are always down (and this game is only playable online...which is a terrible idea for this game) but because of bugs: the game keeps thinking that I haven't yet finished the tutorial, so every other game-crash (like every 5 mins) it keeps making me play the tutorial. There is NO OPTION TO SKIP the tutorial. It's like groundhog day, but I've actually paid money to be stuck in it.Tried the 'recovery' mode and chat with Customer Service, both to no avail.Avoid this game, at least for several months. They have a lot of work to do.

title: Sadly wont work on Mac
body: I bought this being super excited but was let down when I found out it would not work on a Mac so I played it for hours in my friends pc but still a great game

title: The game is broken
body: EA has made an horrible game, everything is broken starting from the server, the DRM, the simulation, the traffic, the zoning strategies, the map size, the multiplayer interaction, the graphical bugs, the utility vehicules dispatching system,... To name a few.

title: What a disappointment
body: I easily installed the game, but for the rest of the evening I was unable to connect to a server - this after they added two new game servers.  The game kept telling me the servers were available, but when I tried to connect it would say it was unable to.  I miss the days when the game was on my computer so I didn't have to depend on them to play.

title: POS GARBAGE, basura! Should be ILLEGAL TO SELL AT THIS POINT. WASTE OF Valuable 20hr, (tryin to login/update/download) TIME.
body: SCUMBALL EA, WISH THEY DIDN'T MAKE THIS DRM!!! I would be calling into work by now in awe.However they have totally ruined SimCity experience for millions of loyal fans and paying customers and the franchise (maybe this was their objective). I PROMISE never to buy another EA, Origin, or subsidary product to these vultures. Currently on HOLD of 60+ minutes to GET MY MONEY BACK!!!

title: Great Game
body: Great game -- There seems to be a lot of complaint but I haven't had any problems really. As long as you don't connect to the North American servers, you're fine. No crashes, nothing.

title: BROKEN
body: I just don't understand how EA can ignore their customers so much. I pre-ordered this game, I sign on every few weeks and play and EVERY TIME after 6-10 hours of game play, some bug shows up that ruins the entire region, and because you can not save the game and go back to before the bug happened, you have to through out the last 10 hours of work and start all over. It completely kills the fun.The maps are too smallThe AI is terribleThe great works fail to sync completely breaking the entire regionOnly one offramp into the city creates an impossible traffic nightmare for people actually playing specialized cities designed to work with the region, which defeats the entire purpose on the online multiplayer which they claim is why the need it onlineAnd any specialization takes up so much space that your village sized city of 60k people with only one highway offramp reaches it's limits, can not grow any larger, and gridlock inevitably takes over.I want to love this game so much. If these bugs weren't here. If we could add more onramps to the highway, and annex surrounding land, and the great works bugs were fixed, I could see spending hundreds of dollars in DLC. But as it is now, it is not only unenjoyable, it is actually aggravating to play. I play a game to have fun, not get frustrated and pissed off.I hate you EA. You ruined 3 of my 5 most favorite games of all time. Sim City, Burnout, and SSX. I hate what you do to video games. Releasing them missing features that we had a decade ago claiming our machines can't handle them.... well they did in the 90's. Releasing half finished games promising to finish them but never do. And worse of all, nickel and diming us on DLC that should be part of the initial game for the price you sell it as.I hope you sell Maxis sometime in my lifetime so we can have a decent version of Sim City. It's been over 10 years since Sim City 4! come on!

title: Why? Why would you sell a game that is not ready for prime time release?
body: Save your money! This was not a well thought out release. Servers and game errors left and right. Just a poor, poor release from EA. Stick to small time games from indie labels. EA is not even trying anymore. Everyone should demand thier money back

title: Seriously horrible
body: I got the game, and was not pleased. I can't even play the game most of the time because of not being able to connect to the servers.

title: Not much of a review to give, can't play it.
body: Bought the game recently because I enjoyed past Sim City games and thought long awaited revamp of the game would be just as good. You can't play without an Internet connection and I can't connect to the servers to play. Don't waste your money.

title: A Lesson in History
body: DIABLO SHOWED YOU WHAT NOT TO DO, AND YOU WERE LIKE 'F*** IT, I'M DRUNK.'STOP MAKING GAMES IF YOU ARE GOING TO TURN A DEAF EAR TO THE CONSUMERS

title: A faux pas, vampires, the love of a good coat, and singing.
body: The other reviews will tell you the technical reasons you shouldn't buy this game, but I'll give you a social reference point for consideration.I could walk into a funeral home admits the beginnings of a funeral, loudly stomp my way into center of the proceedings, approach the casket. From within my coat, I could pull out a stake and mallet for all to see and start pounding the stake into the chest of the recently deceased, in perfect view of his grieving family all the while screaming 'I banish you Nosferatu back to the hell from which you came!'.I could then pour gasoline on the corpse, set it alight and urinate the fire out,.. claw my way up the curtains, turn and perform a perfect cannonball into the casket. (spraying wood, flesh, and various embalmmants all over the group of mourners.)If I did all those things then stood up dusted myself off and proceeded to grope to the newly widowed wife while sexually gratifying myself on the sleeve of her terrified daughter's coat singing the Brunnen-G death song from LEXX, I *STILL* would have created less of a social faux pas than to ever suggest that one of my friends buy this game.Yo Way Yo.

title: Sigh...
body: DRM issues aside, the game itself is a lopsided mess of unplayable sequences. Glitches run rampant, the sims themselves are dumb, and the city is so amazingly limited that I returned my copy within eight hours.This represents all that is wrong with the modern video gaming industry:-Trying to be innovative in all the wrong places, ruining what makes games fun-Sticking to its guns and remaining conservative in all the wrong places, leading to the Maddens and the Call of Duties-Real innovative games that are fun and compelling aren't even given two glances and some are scrapped before release just because they're 'not commercial enough'...-Releasing unfinished, buggy games with the intent of patching it later for extra money- without thinking that the game is hit or miss and many people might abandon the game.Sim City isn't a game, it's a warning. Our final warning. The last warning of the 7th Generation.The game itself, as I said, isn't good. Go with SimCity 4, download some patches, gameplay mods, and graphical mods, and voila. Certainly a much better experience than this trainwreck.

title: Great game when you can actually play it!!
body: EA really dropped the ball here. I payed $90 for digital download and have only been able to play here and there for 2 days due to server issues. Game is fun and addictive but having an online only game and then not being able to support it is unforgivable.

title: Invasive DRM
body: I loved the Sim franchise growing up, and when I heard they were finally doing a remake I was super excited.  I soon found out it was going to be on Origin only, which after bad experiences with Mass Effect 3 meant I would not be buying this product.  While the game looks like it is interesting, it seems too dumbed down from its predecessors.

title: Don't but this game, waste of $60
body: I can't believe I waited 3 months watching videos of the beta release on youtube of this game.  The servers are slow/crash during the middle of a game, you can't save your city, the building space for a city is really small, and I've had to spend 60 minutes just to START a game.  wtf?

title: Sorry ea
body: This will be the last DRM game I ever buy. I  have had the game going on two days now, and I have yet to be able to play it. I can understand the always online as a way to really stick it to used sales and piracy, even if I don't agree. I can also understand that they want to milk your wallet for every last dime. (ex sims 3 is 30$, with ALL the dlc is well over 400...for a single game.)What I can't understand is why you would make a game always DRM and not be able to support it. The servers are a mess, and if it only effected the multiplayer that would be one thing, but you can't play this game single player on your own PC, have to play on theirs through yours. which means in 2 or 3 years when EA stops funding it, the servers will go off line and your $400+ video game will no longer work. Period. Guess its time to dust off the ps1 and play some sim city 2000, that still works.

title: SHE'S A WITCH!
body: ARGGGHH!!! She's a witch I tell you! I saw her praying to her evil gods and conjuring up her spells in the cellar. We must burn her at once to stop the evil from spreading into our village! BURNN HER! BURN WITCH, DIE!!!

title: Horrible
body: If I could rate this game lower I would.I was really excited to get this game and I preordered it due to all the hype.I'm sorry I bought it. EA should be ashamed of this game. It bogs down and is buggy. I constantly get an error saying the game is unstable and it crashes, losing all of my progress.In short, don't buy it.

title: Fantastic Game Ruined by EA's Incompetence...
body: First let me say, I love this game.  I'm a big fan of SimCity, and this new version is an excellent upgrade.  The problem is, you CAN'T PLAY this game without being connected to EA's Origin servers.  If you loose your network connection to Origin, the game literally stops and prevents you from playing.  If I was not such a fan of SimCity, this alone would have prevented me from buying it.  Unfortunately, that's just the beginning of the pain.EA's Origin servers have been a constant problem.  It can take hours to get connected to them.  When you do get connected, you often can't continue resume a game you previously started. The server then go down constantly.  Even when you can get and stay connected for any stretch of time, you can't send or receive friend requests, and you can't invite friends to your game.Those of us who have played other EA games recently, should not be surprised.  I'm scolding myself for buying this game, knowing that it was an EA title, and it would require a connection to Origin.  I very much regret this purchase.By requiring a connection to Origin to play, EA has ruined SimCity.  It is quite literally unplayable.  Until SimCity can be freed from EA's incompetence, don't buy.

title: Spent 6 hours Installing and Updating - Yet to play
body: Spend over 6 hours on 2 different days Installing and updating. Everytime I try to play it takes more than an hour to update then will not play. I get messages like 'Server Busy' 'Server Not Available' or 'Server Down For Maintenance'. Why is a single player game REQUIRE online connection to a server!?!?! Yes, it may be nice to play with friends from time to time, but when I play Sim City I really dont NEED to play with others.

title: Currently unplayable
body: 2nd day of release and most servers are "available" however still can’t create or claim cities, join other games in progress and if lucky enough to get a game started it crashes in 10~15 mins with all progress lost.  (start over)  Game is awful and I don’t think time is going to improve it.  Even if it did work and For me it has not, this game makes Home front look like GOTY in comparison

title: Horrible Horrible Horrible
body: Would be nice to actually play the game.  Online only play was manufactured by the geriatric scrooges at EA whose only interest is the money in their pockets.

title: Don't buy this game thinking you'll be playing it any time soon.
body: It has now been two days and I still cannot play this $60 game.. Unfortunately I did not purchase this from Amazon, but from Origin/EA.  They now have the nerve to state NO REFUNDS will be given!  I am currently in contact with my credit card company disputing the charge, which EA states will have me BANNED from my account! What Nerve, if you haven't bought this game... I would save my money & headache.  Total FAIL SimCity/Maxis/EA!

title: Unplayable Fraud - Destruction of the Franchise
body: Sim City 5 (confusingly called Sim City by EA) requires a constant internet connection to play.  Somehow EA didn't have the servers set up to actually handle people playing the game.  Despite paying $60 for the game I've been unable to play a single minute in my first 48 hours of owning the game.  Servers are unavailable, the game fails to load, and EA is completely unhelpful.  There's no venue to even complain to them about the game.  Do not buy this game--you won't be able to play it for weeks until they figure out their mess.Having played the beta, the granularity offered to users is frustratingly simple and basic tasks take multiple clicks through confusing menus.  Sim City 4 was a great game that was well designed to last the test of time.  Sim City 5 is just a poor attempt at a multiplayer cash cow with microtransactions.  It alienates the core gamers who have grown up playing the previous Sim City games.  There's glossy videos and pictures of great-looking cities for sure, and the graphics are refreshing, but the gameplay is as dull as watching grass grow and it's an insult to those who paid to be first to experience its failure.I'm willing to revise my rating if EA ever fulfills their end of the contractual agreement and allows me to actually play that game.  But until then, I waste hour after hour dealing with errors, update downloads, and cities that continually disappear rather than saving in the 'cloud' like they are supposed to.

title: The game simply does not work

title: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!
body: I was an idiot and purchased two copies so my husband and I could play together. We even upgraded his machine so we could play. Big waste of over $250! The first night was a disaster. Installing went fine if you can account for Origin being very UN-user friendly. Most the servers were busy and Oceanic, just forget it that server is completely jacked. At that time I didn't know it was completely online but I play a ton of MMO's so I can deal. The tutorial kept hanging up and wouldn't start. Finally we got it to start.This is not where the issue ended, first of all the tutorial is junk. Half of the things we learned we learned by mistake. It took me forever to figure out how to invite him to a game with me. HINT: It's hidden under all the other garbage. Half way through the game my town started to glitch out, I got stuck with a ton of protesters despite the fact what they were protesting was not happening. Followed by that a random event resulted in the loss of my entire town. My husband couldn't figure out why this was happening.I thought this was maybe just first day problems. However, we tried to play again today and after massive server hopping to finally get to a server where we could create a game, I tried to invite my husband and no matter where we went we were met with the same 'You can not  invite that player at this time, please try again.' After about 30-45 mins we said forget it and we went to go watch a movie.I work full time and have a small child and I do not mind paying the extra money to play a game to relax and enjoy at the end of the day. This is not it. My husband is fed up and is calling EA tomorrow.Whatever you do, DO NOT buy this game. At this point I am not even sure they will fix it. As a project manager, they need to fire their project team cause their programmers and producers did NOT do their jobs. Worst go-live I have ever seen.

title: Bored after 4 weeks.
body: The GOOD:Graphic are very nice. Switching between cities is easy and fast. You have curved roads now. You can build and Archology now as it was possible in SC2000.The BAD:Trying to get resources to the Archology in order to get it built is a pain and often in vain (Lack of control in where to ship your products)I paid out over $80 for the 'Deluxe Version' and it's not worth it. The extra little buildings aren't that impressive. Stick with the Limited You'll be happier and won't feel ripped off by EA.I can't understand why these guys didn't/don't listen to the the gamers and see what their insight is. I've spent hundreds of hours on SC4 and know what I want and SC5 has not delivered.UPDATE*****I've been playing this game for about 4 weeks now. EA has managed to add servers and connectivity problems have been resolved. Overall this game is NOT like the old SimCity4 game. You can't manage infrastructure to the level of SC4, they made it for a lack of a better phrase, 'idiot proof'. It's been over simplified. The Financial management has also been reduced to simply taxes etc. You can't really manage education, fire departments, Police etc. You have the choice to simply close a school etc. Mass transit is also severely limited. There are no more subways, you can't build highways.With health issues, there is a 'germy' factor where you can deploy health vehicles that visit homes to 'teach' sims to live healthier. But even if you have a healthy home for the Sims the messages continue to state 'this place is germy'The maps are too small and the feel of the city is not at all what it was like in SC4. You also cannot control your exports on a level that would make it possible to whom you want to ship your Product. In this version you simply plop RCI, plop schools, other minor infrastructure and hope for the best. You also cannot plop building unless there is a road present, which makes it very difficult to determine where you would like your buildings placed. The 'grid snap' feature for roads can be helpful, but many times it 'snaps' a road to point that you simply do not want and can be very annoying.It is difficult to run a profitable city and the balance between unemployment and unfilled jobs is sporadic at best. So far I have not been able to balance employment. Simply put this game needs more work.So far I have not heard if there can be custom building made for this game as in SC4 but I have a feeling that since it's a server based game the answer is no.My final opinion of this game:It is interesting at first, I have pretty much lost interest and am very disappointed in the game itself. It is nothing like SC4 and you can see that Will Wright was not involved in the making of this game. Another miss for EA. Perhaps they should start listening to the gamers so they can understand what we are actually looking for. It is obvious that they are not hardcore SimCity4 players nor have they played it for many years.Hope this helps. I'm going to play SimCity 4 now. Good luck!!!difficult to determine where you would like your buildings placed. The 'grid snap' feature for roads can be helpful, but many times it 'snaps' a road to point that you simply do not want and can be very annoying.It is difficult to run a profitable city and the balance between unemployment and unfilled jobs is sporadic at best. So far I have not been able to balance employment. Simply put this game needs more work.So far I have not heard if there can be custom building made for this game as in SC4 but I have a feeling that since it's a server based game the answer is no.My final opinion of this game:It is interesting at first, I have pretty much lost interest and am very disappointed in the game itself. It is nothing like SC4 and you can see that Will Wright was not involved in the making of this game. Another miss for EA. Perhaps they should start listening to the gamers so they can understand what we are actually looking for. It is obvious that they are not hardcore SimCity4 players nor have they played it for many years.Hope this helps. I'm going to play SimCity 4 now. Good luck!!!

title: Fun for hours, frustration for days
body: I would really like to give this game 4 or 5 stars for its potential.  I really want to give this game 1 or 2 for being the most colossal screw-up of a video game I've ever seen.  I gave it 3 stars because I have fun playing it for 2-3 hour segments before the bugs drag my cities down and the memory of $60 leaving my bank account returns to my brain.  There's a patch coming tomorrow, but I expect even 6 months from now this review will read much the same.  Highways turn into parking lots, budgets turn into nightmares, and you realize that EA has a long way to go before this game is worth purchasing when all the power and water your neighbor is giving you disappears when the server fails to sync.I did manage to get the Sims 3 out of this purchase after quite a lot of frustration, so that's a +1 star right there.  What's bad about Simcity is the issues it has were so easy to see coming that I don't know why I keep pre-ordering EA products.  Simcity 4 had traffic problems but not so bad that your city literally came to a halt.  The lack of real estate for building cities is something I expect to be solved eventually, so I will give EA the benefit of the doubt on that.  As for the lack of subways, atrocious highway design, no custom terrain, and the sheer number of game breaking bugs too numerous to list, I don't know how EA didn't delay this game a month to save their reputation even if it damaged sales.It looks great and plays great when it is working.  Beautiful game.  I never wanted a refund even when I couldn't access the game at the beginning.  The primary reason I advise against buying this game for anything more than $10-$20 is because when your city is aflame, covered in garbage, and has an impending disaster about to hit your last chance at balancing the budget, you'll wish you could say, "wow, I did that!"  Instead, you find yourself zooming in on that single blocked mass transit bus that strangled your city to death and wonderwhat piece of code caused that catastrophe.There is nothing more comical and sad than watching a robber stuck in traffic for 6 hours while the police car behind it waits patiently in traffic, sirens blaring, only for the criminal to get away by pulling into his driveway.EA does have a history of patching and patching, so here's hoping they patch this into the game we all expected.  I'm tired of being unable to share resources between my own cities when that was kinda the whole point.

title: Everyone here keeps bitching, but...
body: Ok, you're going to see a lot of terrible reviews for this game, but I simply ask you to ignore them.  They're written by self-entitled 12-year-olds that have nothing to do but cry about the changes in the game that they don't like.  They can get over it, honestly; this game isn't that bad.  Most of them are even copy and pasting each other's complaints because they don't want to seem ignorant - when we all know they are anyway.So, here's the deal:The game is completely online which is GREAT when it's actually available - as you may know, like any other game that functions completely online(LoL and WoW coming to mind) sometimes it is unavailable due to server saturation.  The problem is that people don't know a damn thing about how that process works and just expect it to, when it's a lot more complicated than they think.  While this game did have server problems, as of today most of them have been dealt with and people who have bought the game are also receiving a free copy of an EA game to compensate for the issues.The city sizes are small for two reasons:  Increases the amount of attention you pay to one area and because some people wouldn't be able to run larger cities on their current computers. People list this as a bad thing, of course, but it isn't at all.  Sure, you can't build endlessly in one slot anymore, but that's not what this specific game is about.  It's all about extreme micro-managing combined with community participation.  The WHOLE point of the game is to build multiple cities and have them thrive by running off of each other.  To go even further, the fun of it comes from OTHER PEOPLE who join your game so that you can work together and supply each other in areas that you're weak in.  A lot of people are trying to play this game by themselves, and that's simply not how it's meant to be played.Another thing that people are complaining about and shouldn't be is how long it takes to develop a city.  Since when do people care that it takes a small amount of time to do something in a video game?  Like, OMG I can build a whole city in 5 hours what a rip off.  I mean, come on...seriously?  You're complaining that you can technically play through a game in five hours while still having fun?  I don't get it.  Some of us have things to do outside of spending 13 hours a day playing SimCity and if that's you, then this isn't the game for you at all.  I'm not saying you can't play the game for that long, as in any SimCity problems will always arise that need your attention.  But, again, that isn't what this game is about.  The whole idea behind the cloud system is that you can play it in micro bursts anywhere that has an internet connection.  Not to mention, building one city doesn't mean you're done.  As I said before, that isn't the point.  This game is focused on you building multiple cities that mutually contribute to each other in order to have the best region in the game - yes, there are leaderboards for a reason.Anyway, those are some of the biggest complaints.  This game doesn't suck, it's just different from other SimCity titles in that their focus was placed somewhere else.  I've thoroughly enjoyed it since I've bought it and have even suggested it to friends who are enjoying themselves with it as well.  Don't listen to these sarcastic fools crying about the changes in the game, buy it and check it out for yourself.

title: I could get over the DRM if the multiplayer component was better implemented
body: Let me start by saying the graphics are very good.  I love building my cities with their specialties, but once you've built about 5 cities each with its own specialty you feel as though you've built everything in the game.  Keep in mind though that the multiplayer nature of regions should make the game fun to play over skype with friends, but the regions themselves have several blaring issues.  In the region I play with my friend we've attempted 3 great works, only the city initiating the great work seems to be able to interact and donate resources to it.  Now the great works may be just one part of the game, but it is the most important multiplayer component as it is something my cities and my friend's cities should be able to work on together for our region.  Other than talking in skype the multiplayer nature of the game includes sending money to each other and building our cities independently of each other with a pop up on occasion saying my police, or fire department is helping out his city or vice versa.  In other words the multiplayer nature of this game is a joke and I feel like we're playing two separate games with the option of looking at his city.I would give the game 4-5 stars if the following were true-It allowed you to build a single city with a friend (ie two mayors) it would be difficult to build a city but it would be an interesting option to try.- The great works actually allowed for us to have multiple cities donate to them (some people experience this problem others do not, I am experiencing this problem).- The cities were larger (while the small cities themselves aren't a deal breaker I find as the density increases I have no room to expand essential infrastructure, waste, water, power, etc.)- Had a subway system (this game is perfect for a subway system, since land is so valuable why not implement an underground transportation solution?)- Had a farming city specialty (This would be an awesome addition,you cover freight 'generic', computers, tv's, alloy, plastics, etc. why not food?)  I would love to build a farming city in this game and it makes sense to have food for your Sims right?

body: Update 2(Mar 21): Still 2 stars, downgrading fun value to 2 stars. Cheetah speed remains disabled, crippling the game. Minor updates continue, failing to address the core issues. title: I was so excited: but its Just awful!
body: I was so excited. but this  just sucks. i wish i had listened to other peoples reviews. it was a giant waste of money.  not worth a penny.>first off, you need a CONSTANT internet connection.>and at least windows 8, windows 7 glitches.>I had the game for 6 hours, only been able to play for 2.  took  an hour and a half to install. and the server keeps crashing so it kicks me off.>the graphics are better, but there is a lot of uncontrolled motion and it makes me sick.>they simplified a lot of things but made other things more confusing.>lower budget and WAY SMALLER cities.>you don't need the disk in to play, might as well download off the internet.>the sandbox mode gives you tons of money and everything is unlocked, but it doesnt matter  because no one will ever move into your city.( no one i have talked to has gotten this to work)ie: your power plant needs workers. but no one will move to your city  without power. but you cant have power until enough people move there to work at the power plant. spent most of the day going round and round on this.>the roads are very difficult to make straight, and it doesnt help that all of the cities are crooked.>there arent many regions at all on a given server.>the music is better.overall very slow, glitchy and frustrating.there really isnt anything redeeming about this game so far.

title: Ignore the online-only arguments: The game is broken beyond even that
body: The new SimCity game has brought with it a significant amount of controversy about whether or not its online connection is really 'necessary' for the game. This discussion, though important, has served as a distraction from a very real problem.The game is broken.The advanced algorithms that direct and track traffic throughout your city and region simply do not work. Traffic takes illogical and often flat-out incorrect routes for no apparent reasons. Traffic will cause a traffic jam while trying to take a two-lane dirt road, completely ignoring a wide open, double-wide avenue that is only slightly less convenient. With logic like this you simply cannot properly manage traffic.It gets worse. Traffic does not only include cars. SimCity treats all resources, services, citizens, and mass transit as traffic. Schools are not able service their areas because students are treated as traffic and subject to the same faulty logic.Police and fire coverage are treated as traffic. Garbage services are traffic.Electricity and water are traffic.And the same faulty logic hobbles each and every one of these aspects of city planning.SimCity is broken, possibly beyond repair. The discussions of online play are clouding the real issue, and until this underlying element of play is fixed, the game should be avoided at all costs.

title: 60 bucks for this?
body: If you are going to require me to play online......make server space so I can. Also, let you saved region load across servers

title: Should have known better
body: I bought 2 copies of this so my brother and I, who live in the same house, could play together.  We were excited with the fact that we could finally play a Sim City game with each other and with other people.Being that it is an EA game though, I should have known that if I wanted the true experience of the game, I should have re-mortgaged my house, prayed to the heavens that EA's servers would actually work, and wait for the alignment of the moon, sun, galaxy, and outlying universe to actually try playing the game.Since installing, it has been nothing but a big headache.  Every time I launch it, I am forced to go through the tutorial before I can try playing the game myself.  This is extremely annoying.  I have tried numerous times to create a game so my brother and I could play and have received errors numerous times about "try again later".  We finally got a new game going and he and I were almost happy.  We were building our cities and going along fine until we got booted.  After logging in again, the data was lost and I had to do the tutorial yet again.Then there is the constant advertising about upgrading to the Deluxe Edition and how much content I am missing out on.  I get that they want to make money, they are a business after all, but when I tell you no, don't bug me about it every 5 minutes.If I could return this product, I would.  I absolutely hate it.  I used to love the Sim City franchise, but EA has bastardized it and taken all the fun out of it.

title: DRM Problems
body: It's impossible for those of us with an unstable internet connection. I was hoping to be able to use it to pass the time on long flights / journeys, as it's the only time I really have to play it. Shame.

title: Ditto
body: Last Update:  Server issues are only a prelude to the true disappointment.  This game is pretty buggy and not a lot of fun.  Tiny little cities and not many features.... There are not enough expensive expansion packs (which I am sure EA has in the works) that will make this worth the effort.  Mine is going back.  Thanks for taking this disaster off my hands Amazon!Update:  After the GM of Maxis came out on Friday and said that they fixed their server issues and added a new server and many more users could be accommodated, I thought I would try again.  Four days and I still have not successfully connected.  Yesterday, the 'game' just sat and spun its wheels literally all day. Most recently this morning I get this error:  'ERROR CODE SMCY-19: Could not communicate with the SimCity update server. Please see the customer support link for help.'  When I click on the 'Learn More' link, it takes me to a webpage that says:  'An error occurred!' in 48 point font.  LOL. Yes, yes, it did.Thanks Maxis and Origin!  Great job!..................What a mess!  After ruining The Sims, with Sims 3, EA had to go and ruin SimCity too.  I could not be more disappointed.
